text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single-column text beginning with a large historiated initial in the left margin; the roundel occupies the full height of six lines of text, with the main text block continuing directly to its right. The initial is integrated into the text block, with the following lines indented to accommodate its width. Wide margins contain vine-scroll extensions of the initial.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with uniform vertical strokes and regular diamond-shaped finials, extensive use of abbreviations and ligatures

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf is reserved for the halo, background field outside the roundel, crown and regalia, emphasizing divine or royal authority. Ultramarine provides a deep celestial field for the figure. Vermilion and green appear in the surcoat and ground line, creating a triadic balance. White highlights on mail and folds model form. Pigments are well preserved with minimal darkening.

features: Single full-length figure at center of circular frame
Halo and crown aligned along vertical axis
Figure’s right foot slightly overlapping the frame

decorative_elements: Interlaced foliate extensions forming the initial’s stem
Acanthus leaf and tendril scrolls in the margin
White penwork detailing within blue field of roundel

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown ink, with varying line weight to delineate mail links and facial features
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal parallel hatching in chainmail and surcoat folds, with lead-white highlights for volume
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and ground-line device; no attempt at linear perspective

content_theme.scene_description: A single full-length figure occupies a circular historiated initial ‘D’, identified as King David. He stands centrally on a green ground line within a deep ultramarine roundel. He wears a gold crown and halo, chainmail hauberk under a red surcoat edged in gold, and gold chausses. His right hand holds a long gilt sceptre topped with a fleur-de-lys motif; his left holds a globus cruciger. A short sword hilt peeks at his left hip. The roundel rim is lined in white penwork and rests on the letter’s curved stroke; the king’s right foot slightly overlaps the frame. The frontal, hieratic posture emphasizes authority. The figure’s garments are rendered with linear mail detailing and minimal shading. Below the roundel, the black-textura lines of the psalm text continue, the first six lines indented to frame the initial. The border extensions of the letter feature scrolling acanthus leaves and interlace in red, green, blue, and gold, linking image to text as a visual marker for the beginning of the Psalms.

religious: King David wearing crown, halo, chainmail and red surcoat

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, hair-side and flesh-side distinction faint; evenly prepared surface with evidence of fine pumicing and uniform thickness; ruled with plummet underdrawing visible under UV
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent: pigments remain vibrant, minimal flaking of red areas, slight abrasion to gold leaf in upper right quadrant of roundel, no major stains, margins intact
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso beneath gold leaf for halo and background punchwork
Underdrawing in brown ink visible under UV in figure’s outline
Regular pricking and ruling for text alignment
Gold punchwork forming a diaper pattern in the outer frame

secondary_functions: Display of patron’s wealth and devotion

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This historiated initial depicting King David inaugurates the Psalms in a high-quality Gothic Psalter, likely produced in a northern French workshop c. 1250–1270. The use of sumptuous ultramarine and burnished gold leaf signals both the economic resources of the patron and the theological importance of David as the psalmist–king. The execution in Gothic textura quadrata, with its disciplined verticality and precise pen flourishes, reflects the professional scriptoria practices of the period. The iconography—crown, halo, sceptre and globus cruciger—fuses royal and divine attributes, prefiguring Christ’s kingship and underscoring the typological link between Old and New Testament. Decorative elements, such as the acanthus scrolls and punched gold diaper surrounding the roundel, bear witness to the influence of Parisian illumination and the English Channel school’s penchant for intricate border work. Technically, the raised gesso underlayer and white highlighting demonstrate advanced material knowledge and refined brushwork characteristic of leading mid-13th-century ateliers. Compared with contemporary Psalters—such as the Psalter of Blanche of Castile—this leaf shares a bold color palette and formal restraint, yet innovates in its integration of royal regalia into a biblical figure. Overall, the page exemplifies the intersection of personal devotion, monastic liturgy, and dynastic self-representation in Gothic manuscript culture.
